{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, along with the physical examination finding of tenderness over the right upper quadrant, suggest a gallbladder issue. The fact that the pain is severe enough to make her stop breathing when deeply palpated in the area is known as a positive Murphy's sign, which is indicative of acute cholecystitis. The lab results show an elevated leukocyte count and slightly elevated liver enzymes, which can be seen in acute cholecystitis. The normal serum amylase and lipase levels rule out acute pancreatitis. The normal serum calcium level also does not suggest acute pancreatitis, which can cause hypocalcemia. The ultrasound exam causing tenderness when the probe presses down on her right upper quadrant further supports the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. The question does not mention the presence or absence of gallstones on the ultrasound, so we cannot definitively say whether this is calculous or acalculous cholecystitis. However, acute calculous cholecystitis is much more common than acute acalculous cholecystitis.", "answer_choice": "A. Acute calculous cholecystitis"}
